Table 3 Catalyst H2 adsorption (μmol g−1) Peak I Peak II Total β-Mo2C – 136.8 136.8 0K-Cu/Mo2C 78.4 99.2 177.6 1K-Cu/Mo2C 36.3 90.9 127.2 2K-Cu/Mo2C 26.7 78.1 104.8 4K-Cu/Mo2C 22.5 34.4 56.9 Highly active K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts for reverse water gas shift reaction: Effect of potassium Jingjing Xu Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft Xingxing Gong Methodology Validation Data curation Rongrong Hu Funding acquisition Project administration Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Zhong-wen Liu Conceptualization Methodology Software Zhao-tie Liu Formal analysis Key Laboratory of Syngas Conversion of Shaanxi Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an, Shaanxi 710119, China Key Laboratory of Syngas Conversion of Shaanxi Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University Xi'an Shaanxi 710119 China Key Laboratory of Syngas Conversion of Shaanxi Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an, Shaanxi 710119, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts with different K loadings were prepared for the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction. The results showed that the incorporation of potassium into the Cu/β-Mo2C catalyst significantly increased CO2 conversion and CO selectivity at an optimal K loading. The remarkable catalytic performance of the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst was due to the presence of highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles and the improved CO2 activation and dissociation caused by the structural and electronic effect of potassium. The presence of K also suppresses H2 adsorption and inhibits the methanation of CO2. The gas switching experiments and in-situ DRIFTS analyses suggest that both the redox and associative mechanism coexists in the RWGS reaction and that the formate species act as the intermediates in converting CO2 to CO for the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Reverse water gas shift reaction Molybdenum carbides Potassium Structural and electronic effects Reaction mechanism Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the most widely known greenhouse gas. The concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased from approximately 277 ppm in 1750 to 407.38 ± 0.1 ppm in 2018 due to the anthropogenic emissions from the consumption of conventional fossil fuels [1,2]. The increasing CO2 emissions are leading to irreversible climate change that will have a lasting impact on our planet. Currently, 2.5 billion tons of CO2 are emitted each year [1], while the consumption of CO2 through catalytic conversion is only 207 million tons [3], less than 1% of total emissions from human activities. According to the Paris Agreement, CO2 emissions related to energy and industry must be significantly reduced after 2030 [1] and that CO2 should be converted into chemicals with added value as raw materials through various processes. One of the potential processes, known as the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, has attracted extensive attention for years [4]. The RWGS reaction allows for the reduction of carbon dioxide to CO on a large industrial scale, and CO is a desirable product because it can further react with H2 to generate liquid hydrocarbons and oxygenates via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [5,6], whereas CH4 is undesirable in RWGS due to its low volumetric energy density and difficulties in transport and storage [7]. Nowadays, lots of research has been carried out on the catalysts for the RWGS reaction, especially on the supported catalysts with dual functions of metal sites and carriers, such as Pt/CeO2 [8], Ni/SiO2 [9], Ni/Ce-Zr-O [10], Au/SiO2 [11] and Cu/SiO2 [12]. The highly dispersed metal particles on the support facilitate the activation of CO2 molecules and the desorption of CO, resulting in high CO selectivity. In addition to the supported metal catalysts, transition metal carbides (TMCs) such as Mo2C [7,13,14], TiC [15] and WC [16] are also considered attractive candidates for the RWGS reaction because of their low cost and similar chemical behaviors to that of precious metals. Among these TMCs, Mo2C exhibits the special catalytic properties in C = O bond scission and H2 dissociation [7,17]. The high intrinsic activity of Mo2C stems from its binding to CO2 in a bent conformation, which results in the spontaneous breakage of the C = O bond into CO and surface O species oxycarbide (O-Mo2C). CO can then be desorbed from the surface and oxycarbide is hydrogenated to produce water [18–20]. The DFT and experimental studies have shown that the Mo/C ratio [21–23] and the morphology of molybdenum carbides [13,24] may affect their performance in CO2 hydrogenation. For example, β-Mo2C produced CO, CH4, and CH3OH, while only CO and CH3OH were produced on the α-MoC1-x catalyst [21]. Gao et al. [13] found that the α-MoC1-x nanowires catalyst has higher active and selective for RWGS than β-Mo2C. On the other hand, Mo2C is also promising as good support for the RWGS reaction [14,22,25,26]. Zhang et al. [14] prepared a series of Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts in which the strong interaction between Cu and β-Mo2C significantly promoted the dispersion of copper particles, thus exhibiting excellent activity and stability in RWGS. In addition, modifying Mo2C with a transition metal (e.g., Co) can significantly improve the CO selectivity in this reaction [7], while in the case of metal Ni, it produced more methane [27]. The metal/Mo2C systems exhibited a large variation in the production selectivity depending on the nature of the supported metal [22,27,28]. In other words, the addition of promoting species to Mo2C can further improve the performance by altering the structural and electronic properties of the catalyst [22,26,29,30]. Alkali metals are also used with the Mo2C catalysts to improve the RWGS rates and CO selectivity [31–33]. One of the effects of potassium on Mo2C is an increase in the adsorption capacity of CO2, as it promotes electron transfer and enhances interactions with CO2 molecules [2,31,34]. The theoretical studies have shown that the doping of K leads to a 2.8 kcalmol−1 decrease in the activation barrier for CO formation on K-Mo2C/γ-Al2O3 [31] and a 3.3 eV reduction in the maximum work function on K-promoted Mo2C/Mo(100) surface [35]. The experimental results also proved selectivity toward CO increased from 75% to 95% when potassium was incorporated into a Mo2C-based catalyst [31], and the Cs-Mo2C catalyst reached 100% CO selectivity in the low temperature RWGS reaction [33]. To date, all these studies have focused on elucidating the promotional role of alkali metals [16,31,33,35]: structural effects and electronic effects, whereas the underlying reaction pathways induced by such modifications on the alkali metal-promoted Mo2C catalysts have not been fully revealed so far. The identification of the intermediates and the active sites in the RWGS reaction is still scarce. Moreover, different promotive effects of different K loadings on the activity and selectivity of WGSR have been confirmed [31]. However, this does not imply a thorough understanding of such phenomena. Here, we prepared a series of K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts with different K loadings and investigated the CO2 activation and reaction pathways of RWGS using various characterizations. We also discuss the effect of the combination of K and Cu promoters on the activity of K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C in RWGS and explain why this combination with the appropriate K content leads to the excellent activity, selectivity and stability of the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalyst in RWGS. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The β-Mo2C catalyst was prepared using a conventional temperature programmed carburization (TPC) procedure [14,27]. Briefly, (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O was first calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain the precursor MoO3. Then, MoO3 was milled and sieved to keep particles between 250 µm and 400 µm in size. Next, it was heated to 300 °C at 2 °C/min in a 20% CH4/H2 gas stream, then continued from 300 °C to 675 °C at 1 °C/min and held at 675 °C for 2 h, and finally cooled to room temperature. The Cu/β-Mo2C and K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts were prepared by using a co-precipitation method and the TPC procedure. A certain amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O was mixed with a Cu(NO3)2•3H2O and /or K2CO3 solution at room temperature. The amounts of the Cu(NO3)2•3H2O and /or K2CO3 solutions were variable to reach various loadings. The mixture was then stirred for 3 h and dried at 70 °C using a rotary evaporator, followed by drying at 110 °C overnight. Next, the sample was calcined at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain the CuO-MoO3 or K2OCuO-MoO3 precursor. These precursors were then used to prepare the Cu/β-Mo2C and K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts by the same TPC method. For the 0K-Cu/Mo2C, 1K-Cu/Mo2C, 2K-Cu/Mo2C and 4K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts mentioned herein, the Cu content was fixed to be 5 wt% and the potassium content was 0%, 1%, 2% and 4% based on β-Mo2C, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The textural properties of these catalysts (specific surface areas, average pore size and pore volume) were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. X-ray diffraction analyses (XRD) of these catalysts were performed on a Rigaku diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements of these samples were carried out by a Nova Nano SEM/FEI microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of these catalysts were obtained using a Hitachi H7100 instrument equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) device. Before TEM observation, all samples were sonicated in ethanol for 10 min and dried in air for 30 min before being placed on a pore carbon-coated nickel grid. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out by a Model Max 200spectrometer, using Al Kα radiation as the excitation source. Both the CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) analyses and the CO2 pulses experiments were carried out in an AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an Omnistar TM device. For the CO2-TPD experiment, 50 mg of sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube and activated in 10% H2/N2 at 400 °C for 2 h and cooled to room temperature in an Argon stream. The catalyst was then saturated in a 20% CO2/Ar for 30 min and purged with Argon for another 30 min to remove the excess CO2. Next, the temperature was increased at a rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 600 °C and the CO2 desorption signals were recorded every 6 s. In the CO2 pulses experiments, 50 mg of sample was first activated in the same way and exposed to a stream of purified Argon, and then the system was changed to purge mode. Ten pulses of 20% CO2/Ar were then injected over the catalyst via a 6-way valve connected with 1.00 mL loop. The CO2 and CO signal (m/z = 44 and 28) was recorded using the Omnistar TM device. The contribution of CO2 to signal 28 was considered in order to calculate the production of CO. The gas switching experiments were also performed in the AutoChem II 2920 apparatus. The sample was retreated in 10% H2/N2 at 400 °C for 2 h and purged with Argon for 30 min to remove the remaining H2. Next, 20% CO2/Ar was introduced in the U-shaped quartz tube for 2 min, followed by Argon for 20 min to remove the remained CO2. Subsequently, 10% H2/Ar was introduced into the reactor for another 2 min. The signals of m/z = 2, 18, 28, 40 and 44 were recorded using the Omnistar TM device. In-situ DRIFTS measurements of the RWGS reaction over the catalysts were carried out using a Thermo Nicolet 6700 spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector. The sample was pretreated in 10% H2/Ar at 350 °C for 1 h and then purged with Argon at 100 °C for 1 hour. After the background spectra were recorded, the reactant gasses (H2 = 12.5 mL/min, CO2 = 5 mL/min, Ar = 12.5 mL/min) were introduced into the in-situ reaction cell at 100 - 350 °C to give the information about the reaction products and intermediates. 2.3 Catalytic test The RWGS reaction of the catalyst was performed in a fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 6 mm at atmospheric pressure. 100 mg of catalyst diluted with inert silica (200 mg) was placed in the middle of the quartz tube. Before the RWGS reaction, the catalyst was pretreated in 20% CH4/H2 at a rate of 10 °C/min up to 675 °C for 60 min. Next, the reactor was cooled to the desired temperature under N2 and then the catalyst was exposed to the feed gas with a stream of H2/CO2 at 140 mL/min with a 2.5:1 feed ratio. The catalyst was tested for 2 h per run and the products were analyzed on-line by a gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) detector on a TDX-01 column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization The optimal experimental conditions for preparing the fresh β-Mo2C catalyst were determined by the TPC experiments. The XRD patterns of the carburization samples of the precursor MoO3 at different temperatures are presented in Fig. 1 . The initial precursor of MoO3 underwent three transition stages and it was finally completely converted to β-Mo2C until 675 °C. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the synthesized Cu/Mo2C and K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1, all of these samples consisted mainly of β-Mo2C [JCPDS 35–787] particles. In addition, a new small peak of 2θ = 43.3°, which is characteristic of metallic Cu, could be observed in the 0K-Cu/Mo2C material. The average particle size of Cu was about 12 nm, according to the Scherrer equation. When 1% K was added to the Cu/Mo2C catalyst, the diffraction peak of metallic Cu disappeared, indicating that an appropriate amount of K could promote the dispersion of Cu particles during TPC and the particle sizes of Cu were smaller than the detection limit. More interestingly, when the K content was increased to 2 and 4%, not only the diffraction peaks of metallic Cu appeared again, but also two sharp and intense diffraction peaks of 40.6o and 58.7° corresponding to metallic Mo [JCPDS 42–1120]could be observed on 4K-Cu/Mo2C. Such a result demonstrates that the addition of K directly affected the structural characteristics of the catalysts and promoted the partial reduction of Mo2C, which is in good agreement with the literature results [28,31]. No peaks related to potassium were detected by XRD because of their excellent dispersion. More specifically, the XRD pattern of these K-Cu/Mo2C samples showed the most intensive peak corresponding to (101) of β-Mo2C were shifted to higher 2θ values due to the partial dissolution of Cu2+ ions into the lattice of Mo2C, resulting in shrinking its lattice parameter. It proved a strong interaction between the Cu-Mo2C interface [14,29,36] of all the K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts, whether the addition of K or not. Table 1 shows the specific surface areas, pore sizes and pore volumes of these Mo2C based catalysts. β-Mo2C had a surface area of about 8 m2/g. When doping with copper or potassium, the surface area of the samples was increased by a factor of 2–3. Fig. 2 presented the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions of these Mo2C based samples. In general, all the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts exhibited similar specific surface areas and pore structures. Fig. 2 shows SEM micrographs of the β-Mo2C and K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts. The morphological changes of β-Mo2C in combination with Cu and K can be clearly observed in the SEM study. The pure β-Mo2C material contained irregular clusters and cubic particles with sizes in the submicron range (Fig. 2a). After Cu incorporation, the catalyst was broken down into smaller flaky particles with a size of about 300 nm, which could be attributed to the strong interaction of Cu with the β-Mo2C substrate during the carbonization process (Fig. 2b). As K was further added into the Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts, the appearance of smaller and more uniform grains with the size range of 100–200 nm was observed on the 1K-Cu/Mo2C and 2K-Cu/Mo2C materials (Fig. 2c and d). Interestingly, the particles of 4K-Cu/Mo2C samples (Fig. 2e and f) transformed into denser grains with a further increase of K content. The XRD results showed that the formation of the metallic Mo phase on 4K-Cu/Mo2C. The change in the morphology of 4K-Cu/Mo2C may be related to the appearance of Mo, which means that the addition of K modulates the interaction between Cu and β-Mo2C. Fig. 3 shows the TEM micrographs together with EDS mapping of these β-Mo2C based materials. In Fig. 3a and b, the β-Mo2C phase (101) had a distance of 2.46 Å, which is in good agreement with the XRD pattern of single-phase β-Mo2C. For the 0K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst (Fig. 3c), the average size of Cu particles was about 14 nm, while for 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts (Fig. 3d and e), the size was only around 2-3.5 nm. The interplanar distance was calculated to be 2.09 Å, attributable to the (111) lattice spacing of Cu metal. Thus, the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts showed better metal dispersion than the 0K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst, which is in good line with XRD observations. In other words, the existence of K prevented the aggregation of Cu particles. However, on the other hand, larger Cu sizes of 8–15 nm were observed in the 2K-Cu/Mo2C (Fig. 3g and h) and 4K-Cu/Mo2C (Fig. 3f) samples, depending on the K loading. It showed that the interaction between Cu and β-Mo2C results in the difference in the particle sizes, while the addition of K could change this interaction [37]. Subsequently, EDS maps were used to analyze the distribution of Cu, Mo, K elemental on the surface of the K-Cu/Mo2C materials. The results indicate that molybdenum, potassium and copper were uniformly distributed on 1K-Cu/Mo2C (Fig. 3) with no evident segregation. This result supports the presence of highly crystalline Cu metal on 1K-Cu/Mo2C, as indicated by the TEM and XRD data. For 4K-Cu/Mo2C (Fig. 3i), although a homogeneous distribution of potassium on β-Mo2C can be noticed from the elemental mapping results, there was some aggregation of Cu particles forming several Cu-rich areas. The difference in copper distribution between these catalysts can be explained by the variation in the amount of introduced potassium. The electron-donating properties of the potassium species caused an electron-rich surface around the Mo species [28,31]. When the K content reached 4%, it promoted the formation of the metallic Mo phase, as shown by XRD, thus changing the interaction between Cu and β-Mo2C of the catalysts during the carburization step of the synthesis. Fig. 3 demonstrates the structural differences among these K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C samples, indicating the potassium species can serve as a structural promoter [16,28,31] during the synthesis of K-Cu/Mo2C. To further discuss the promotional effects of the potassium species on Cu/β-Mo2C, the surface sensitive XPS measurements of these K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts were performed (Fig. 4 and Table 2 ). The Mo 3d spectra (Fig. 4a) exhibited two contributions, 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, arising from spin-orbit splitting. The following values were used to deconvolute the XPS data [28,33,37]: Mo0: 227.6 eV, Mo2+: 228.5 eV, Moσ+(2<σ<4): 229.2–231.9 eV, and Mo6+: 232.6 eV ± 0.2 eV. As shown in Fig. 4a and Table 2, the incorporation of potassium into the Cu/β-Mo2C catalyst led to a decrease of the MoO3 (Mo6+) [31,38,39] phase while an increase of Mo2C (Mo2+) [31,36,38,39] and O-Mo2C [31,36,37,39], represented by Moσ+ on the catalyst surface. Moreover, metallic Mo can be found in all the K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts and increased significantly with the increasing K. In other words, in these K-Cu/Mo2C samples, the electron-donating nature of the potassium species leads to the increase of d-orbital occupancy of molybdenum with increasing K content. Thus, these electron-rich surfaces around Mo acquire different degrees of metallic properties, which in turn may lead to the differences in the Cu-Mo2C interface, suggesting that alkali metals play an important role in the chemical environment of Mo [28,37]. Fig. 4b shows the Cu 2p spectra of these samples. XPS spectrum of Cu 2p for these catalysts can be decomposed into six separate peaks. The Cu 2p3/2 BE peak at 931.9- 933.1 eV and the absence of the shake-up peaks are characteristics of the reduced Cu species [36,37,40].The shake-up peaks accompanied by the parental peaks and the Cu 2p3/2 BE peak at 933.0-934.8 eV are the two major characteristics of Cu2+ species [36,37,40]. In Fig. 4b, the Cu 2p3/2 BE at approximately 931.9-932.6 eV was observed for all the catalysts, indicating the presence of reduced Cu species on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, a peak splitting of 19.8 eV was also observed, implying the probable presence of Cu0 or/and Cu1+[14,33,40]. To distinguish Cu1+ and Cu0, the Cu LMM Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) of these samples are shown in Fig. 4c. In the present study, AES spectra exhibited two peaks at 568.2 eV and 569.8 eV, which can be assigned to Cu1+ and Cu0 species [14,33,36], respectively. The measured Cu1+/Cu0 ratios were 0.59, 0.77, 0.78 and 0.85 for 0K-Cu/Mo2C, 1K-Cu/Mo2C, 2K-Cu/Mo2C and 4K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts, respectively. On the one hand, the presence of Cu1+ demonstrates a strong interaction between β-Mo2C and Cu [14,29,36], as indicated by the XRD results. On the other hand, the increase in the Cu1+/Cu0 ratio of the K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts suggests K species does facilitate the electronic transfers from Cu0 to Cu1+ [33,37]. More interestingly, more Cu2+ species could be found on the surface of 2K-Cu/Mo2C and 4K-Cu/Mo2C. It again demonstrates the role of the potassium species in facilitating the electron interactions in these multicomponent catalysts. Potassium can transfer the electron density from Cu to Mo, as well as from Cu0 to Cu1+ even to Cu2+. Fig. 4d shows the K 2p XPS spectra for various K loadings on the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts. The K 2p3/2 signals at 292.2 eV [32,41] significantly increased with increasing K loadings, suggesting a strong interaction between potassium with metal Cu and β-Mo2C substrate. This strong interaction could promote the dispersion of metallic Cu on β-Mo2C, resulting in smaller metallic Cu particles, consistent with the TEM results. Moreover, as we discussed earlier, potassium in Cu/β-Mo2C can lead to an increment in the electron charge density around the Mo species and the appearance of metallic Mo. As it is showed later, the presence of this interfacial K not only helped to improve the conversion of CO2, but also to inhibit the methanation of CO2. 3.2 RWGS performance All these catalysts were evaluated for the catalytic performance of the RWGS reaction under the specified conditions. The results in Fig. 5 present the CO2 conversion and CO selectivity of the Mo2C-based catalysts in the range of 300- 600 °C. As can be seen in Fig. 5a, the CO2 conversion of all these catalysts increased with increasing temperatures. On the pure β-Mo2C catalyst, the CO2 conversion was only 1.2% at 350 °C, monotonically increasing to 26.7% at 600 °C, while the initial CO2 conversion was close to 15%, reaching 52.4% at 600 °C on the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst, indicating the worthy advantage in the RWGS reaction. Apparently, the K-modified Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts showed much higher CO2 conversion than β-Mo2C in the temperature range of our experiments, especially at the lower reaction temperature. The 0K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst also had good activity and showed very similar CO2 conversion to 2K-Cu/Mo2C. In terms of selectivity (Fig. 5b), it increased with increasing temperatures for all the catalysts. The possible reason is, at lower temperatures, a small fraction of the CO product adsorbed on the catalyst surface may dissociate and further be hydrogenated to CH4 [19], while at the higher temperature, CO desorption becomes faster [13], leading to higher selectivity of CO. Interestingly, although the CO selectivity of 0K-Cu/Mo2C exceeded 96.9% in the entire temperature range, it was still lower than that of all the K-modified Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts. Clearly, the addition of K had a strong promotive effect, which led to a high CO selectivity (> 99.5%) over the whole temperature range. 3.3 Promotive effect of potassium Such changes to catalytic performance may be reasonably explained by the structural or electronic effects of the added alkali metal promoter. These structural and morphology changes were observed for the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts. It has been proved that the particle size and morphology of the catalysts had affected the catalytic activity. On the other hand, the electronic promotion resulted in a change in the chemical state of Cu and Mo. These may also impact catalytic activity and selectivity. 3.3.1 the role of metallic Mo According to the XRD and XPS data, K can transfer electrons to the surface of β-Mo2C, leading to a metallic-like Mo species. To fully understand the effect of K loading on the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts during RWGS, the activity pattern of the β-Mo2C and Mo/β-Mo2C catalysts was compared in Fig. 5c. The result of Fig. 5c would help to clarify the role of metallic Mo in these catalysts. Here, the Mo/β-Mo2C catalyst was prepared by lowering the carburization temperature of MoO3 to 645 °C during the synthesis process. At this temperature, a mixture of metallic Mo and β-Mo2C is obtained according to the result of Fig. 1. As seen in Fig. 5c, the β-Mo2C catalyst had higher activity and CO selectivity than the Mo/β-Mo2C catalysts over the entire temperature range, indicating the presence of the metallic Mo phase in the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts itself may not be the active sites driving the selectivity towards CO formation. The DFT calculations under RWGS reaction conditions also indicate that the Mo2C(101)-Mo/C surface exhibits balanced binding properties and activates CO2 well toward dissociation, whereas the (201)-Mo/C, (001)-Mo, and (001)-C surfaces could bind CO2 and CO + O intermediates too strongly for a subsequent removal [39]. Therefore, both the calculations and our experiments indicate that the carburization step was responsible for achieving high catalytic activity. Furthermore, Cu2+ species were also present in the XPS spectra of the 2K-Cu/Mo2C and 4K-Cu/Mo2C samples due to the electron transfer promoted by K. The presence of Cu2+ does not explain the high CO selectivity because the active center of the RWGS reaction is closely related to Cu0 and Cu1+. Cu0 is the active site for CO2 hydrogenation and Cu1+ species could enhance CO2 adsorption and stabilize the intermediate formate species [12,40]. However, an increase of Cu2+ in the catalyst also implies a decrease of Cu0, which in turn decreases the catalytic activity. Thus, the lower activity of 4K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts is also related to the low amount of Cu0 and Cu1+. 3.3.2 CO2 adsorption and activation The electron effects also lead to the chemisorption and activation of these catalysts to reactants and intermediates, thus affecting catalytic activity and selectivity. It is well known that potassium as a promoter can improve CO2 adsorption. The CO2 adsorption ability also is an indicator of the strength of the basic sites on the catalyst surface. Fig. 6 shows the CO2-TPD curves of these Mo2C-based catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6, a broad CO2 desorption peak of about 200–400 °C appears in Mo2C. This peak corresponds to the desorption of CO2 moderately adsorbed on the surface of molybdenum carbide [42]. For the 0K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst, a strong and narrow peak was found in the temperature range 300–400 °C with the introduction of Cu metal, indicating strong adsorption of CO2 molecules of 0K-Cu/Mo2C. In general, there was no CO2 desorption peak in the TPD curve of pure metallic Cu [40]. The DFT calculations also found a highly positive binding energy that brings about very unstable chemisorption of CO2 on Cu [43]. However, due to the strong interaction between Cu and Mo species, as confirmed by the XPS results in Fig. 4a and b, the Cu-Mo2C interface provides an additional active site for the adsorption of CO2 molecular. Another interesting finding is that the K-modified Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts possessed more basic sites than the unpromoted ones. More specifically, for the 1K-Cu/Mo2C and 2K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts, not only the peaks belonging to the medium basic sites at 250 °C and 300 °C increased, but also the peak corresponding to the medium-strong basic sites at 350 °C shifted to higher temperatures. These peaks can be attributed to the formation of carbonate species, which is from the interaction of CO2 with the surface basic sites induced by the addition of K [35,44,45]. The presence of potassium could lead to the formation of CO2 − on the potassium-covered Mo2C/Mo(100) surface [35]. That is, K improves the total CO2 uptake due to its inherent basicity. Large numbers of basic sites in the 1K-Cu/Mo2C and 2K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts facilitated the activation of chemisorbed CO2 species compared to Mo2C and 0K-Cu/Mo2C, and their higher basicity also had a stronger affinity for acidic CO2 molecules. Furthermore, it should be noted that the 4K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst had a significantly lower peak at 350 °C compared to 0K-Cu/Mo2C, and we speculate that the excess K species may partially cover the Cu-Mo2C sites on which CO2 was strongly adsorbed. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the potassium species locates at the interfacial site between the metallic Cu particle and the β-Mo2C substrate. In order to obtain more information about the activation of CO2 on the catalyst surface, a CO2 pulse experiment (Fig. 7 a and b) was designed to probe the ability to dissociate CO2 with trace amounts of CO2 over these catalysts. Fig. 7a shows the MS signals from the pulse experiments. Here, the contribution of CO2 to m/z = 28 is calculated to determine the amount of CO production. When a blank run is examined, the response area ratio of the mass signal of 28 to 44 for the CO2 pulse was used as a calibration in our experiments. In Fig. 7a, CO was generated once CO2 was pulsed over the Mo2C and K-promoted Cu/Mo2C catalysts at 400 °C. These results indicate within a very short contact time, CO2 dissociated rapidly over these catalysts, accompanied by the desorption of CO. This is also direct evidence that the reaction at least involved a redox mechanism on these Mo2C-based catalysts, in good agreement with the results in the literature [7,14,18,29]. The molybdenum oxycarbide (O-Mo2C) was then left on the surface [7,17–19]. The DFT calculations showed CO2 can adsorb and dissociate on the oxygen-covered β-Mo2C surface [46], consistent with our experimental results. As shown in Fig. 7a, 1K-Cu/Mo2C possessed the highest CO2 dissociation activity, almost 2.2 and 1.5 times higher than the bare Mo2C and 0K-Cu/Mo2C, respectively. Furthermore, the CO2 activity capacity of these catalysts at 400 °C increased in the order of Mo2C < 4K-Cu/Mo2C < 0K-Cu/Mo2C < 2K-Cu/Mo2C < 1K-Cu/Mo2C. Therefore, the addition of K to Cu/Mo2C facilitated the activation of chemisorbed CO2 species. However, it is noteworthy that although 4K-Cu/Mo2C had higher CO2 adsorption capacity according to the CO2-TPD results, it had a lower dissociation activity in this CO2 pulse experiment. It may be due to the excess K species covering part of the active Cu sites and the decrease in the total amount of active sites Cu0/Cu1+ in the catalysts caused by the strong interaction between Cu and β-Mo2C promoted by K. Fig. 7b shows the accumulation of CO from CO2 dissociation on these catalysts after 10 consecutive CO2 pulses at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 7b, CO production from all catalysts increased with increasing temperature. At 600 °C, 1K-Cu/Mo2C produced 1250 μmol g−1 CO, much higher than that of the β-Mo2C catalyst, again demonstrating the efficiency of the K-Cu-Mo2C combination in the CO2 activation process. The CO2-TPD and pulse experiments showed that K doping improved the adsorption and dissociation of CO2. Thus, the main reason for the high activity of the 1K-Cu/Mo2C and 2K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst can be attributed to the enhancement of CO2 adsorption and reduction of CO2 dissociation barriers due to the presence of potassium. 3.3.4 H2 adsorption The adsorption and activation of H2 also play an important role in RWGS since they may affect CO selectivity. Fig. 8 presents the H2-TPD results of these Mo2C-based catalysts. The H2 desorption profile of pure Mo2C showed one large broad peak of 50–550 °C, assigned to the H2 adsorption of Mo2C surface. For the 0K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst, a new peak was found in the temperature range 100–250 °C, indicating strong activation of H2 molecules on the metallic Cu sites. The introduction of Cu metal shifts the desorption peak of H2 to a lower temperature and contributes to the formation of active H species, which is in good agreement with the well-known hydrogen dissociative behavior on Cu0 [47]. It is worth noting that although hydrogen adsorption and activation also occurred at 100–250 °C for all the K-promoted Cu/Mo2C catalysts, the absolute H2 adsorption amounts decreased considerably, depending on the K loading. The quantified results of H2 adsorption over the samples are presented in Table 3 . From it, the 4K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst has the lowest H2 desorption, indicating the incorporation of alkali metals suppresses H2 adsorption. It has been reported that the selectivity to methane decreased due to the addition of alkalis in F-T synthesis and water gas shift reaction [45,48]. Therefore, the high CO selectivity in K-Cu/Mo2C is most likely due to the weakened H2 adsorption and enhanced CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, resulting in a low H2/COx ratio and thus reducing CH4 production. 3.3.4 the reaction pathway and intermediates in RWGS Furthermore, to get insight into the reaction pathway and the intermediates in RWGS over the K-promoted Cu/Mo2C catalysts, the gas switching experiment was performed on the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst. CO2 and H2 were sequentially introduced into the reactor on the fresh catalyst at 400 °C, while the exit MS signals of CO and H2O production were measured, respectively. Fig. 4 shows that during the first CO2 stream (20% CO2/Ar for 2 min), CO was generated and O-Mo2C species were left on the surface of this catalyst after CO2 dissociation, consistent with the results of the pulse experiments in Fig. 7a. Subsequently, Argon was introduced into the reactor to remove the remaining CO2. However, after the subsequent H2 flow (10% H2/Ar for 2 min), both water and CO were produced, different from the expected redox cycle. The results showed that the redox and associative mechanism coexists in the RWGS reaction of the K-promoted Cu/Mo2C catalysts. It also implied that the presence of the stable carbon-containing surface intermediates, which can interact with the dissociated H species into H2O and CO. More information about these surface intermediates was obtained through the in-situ DRIFTS experiments. Fig. 9 presents the in-situ DRIFTS spectra collected from the 0K-Cu/Mo2C and 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts exposed to H2 and CO2 at 250-350 °C. For the 0K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts, the feature peaks at 3169 cm−1, 2983 cm−1 and 1398 cm−1 appeared at 250 °C are assigned to the bidentate formate species on Mo2C [13,49,50]. The peaks at 1247 cm−1 are ascribed to the bidentate carbonate species [50]. After increasing the temperature to 300 °C, the new peaks at 2177 cm−1 and 2111 cm−1attributed to gaseous CO appear [51], indicating the transformation of formate to CO. Gao et al. [13] reported that the *HCOO species could be found on the surface of β-Mo2C catalyst upon in situ DRIFTS of CO2 and H2 and suggested that the reduction of CO2 to CO on β-Mo2C follows the formate decomposition mechanism. However, with the addition of K, the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst showed different characteristics for the adsorbed species. In addition to the observed *HCOO species over 0K-Cu/Mo2C, two new peaks at 1690 cm−1 and 1510 cm−1 appeared at 250 °C, assigning to the monodentate formate species [52,53] and the monodentate carbonate species [50,54], respectively. It showed that two types of *HCOO species and *CO3 species exist on the K-promoted catalyst surface. The formation of these formate and carbonate species suggested an easier activation of CO2 on the K-promoted Cu/Mo2C catalysts, in good agreement with the CO2-TPD results. The formate species can easily react with adsorbed H and then act as the intermediates in converting CO2 to CO [53], showing another reaction pathway for CO formation. Hence, the doping of K in the Cu/Mo2C catalysts favors the conversion of CO2 to CO in RWGS. 3.4 Stability To examine the stability, the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst was tested for a total of 120 h under different conditions. On series A, the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst was evaluated for 50 h between 400 °C and 600 °C, every 4 h at 600 °C and 1 h at 400 °C. Next, on series B, these catalysts were tested at 600 °C for 70 h. Fig. 10 plots the CO2 conversion and CO selectivity recorded during this experiment. Throughout the experiment, no methanation reaction was taken place. The 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst exhibited a slight deactivation over time, with an 8.4% decrease in CO2 conversion after 120 h on stream. During the first 70 h, there was no significant decrease in CO2 conversion for the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts. The drop in activity was mainly between 70 and 90 h on stream and then remained stable. Overall, the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalysts exhibited excellent selectivity, activity and stability in the RWGS reaction. 4 Conclusion In summary, the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalyst was used as an efficient RWGS catalyst with higher catalytic activity than both β-Mo2C and Cu/β-Mo2C. The results showed that the structural and electronic effects among K, Cu and Mo species boosted the adsorption and activation performances of CO2 molecules on the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts. The 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst with an optimal K loading shows the highest CO2 conversion, 100% CO selectivity, and excellent stability in RWGS. However, excessive addition of potassium significantly reduced the efficiency of the surface-active sites responsible for RWGS due to the electron-donating nature of the potassium species. In addition, the gas switching experiments and in-situ DRIFTS analyses showed that both the redox and associative reaction pathways contribute to the overall RWGS rate on K-Cu/Mo2C and that the formate species act as the intermediates in converting CO2 to CO. The experimental evidence in this work highlights the importance of structural and electronic effects for designing active and stable RWGS catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts with different K loadings were prepared for the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction. The results showed that the incorporation of potassium into the Cu/β-Mo2C catalyst significantly increased CO2 conversion and CO selectivity at an optimal K loading. The remarkable catalytic performance of the 1K-Cu/Mo2C catalyst was due to the presence of highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles and the improved CO2 activation and dissociation caused by the structural and electronic effect of potassium. The presence of K also suppresses H2 adsorption and inhibits the methanation of CO2. The gas switching experiments and in-situ DRIFTS analyses suggest that both the redox and associative mechanism coexists in the RWGS reaction and that the formate species act as the intermediates in converting CO2 to CO for the K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active K-promoted Cu/β-Mo2C catalysts for reverse water gas shift reaction: Effect of potassium
